discussion.content:
Preventing VM escaping is dependent on the virtualization vendor identifying security vulnerabilities in the hypervisor and on these being patched. The impact of VM escaping can be reduced by using effective service design and network placement when deploying VMs.
Isolating VMs in different zones on separate hardware—This should reduce the impact of a VM escaping attack.

questions.question_text: Which of the following should be implemented to stop an attacker from interacting with the hypervisor through another guest?

An internal intranet site is required to authenticate users and restrict access to content to only those who are authorized to view it. The site administrator previously encountered issues with credential spoofing when using the default NTLM setting and wants to move to a system that will be more resilient to replay attacks. Which of the following should the administrator implement?

discussion.content: The answer given is correct. A replay attack consists of intercepting a key or password hash then reusing it to gain access to a resource, such as the pass-the-hash attack. This type of attack is prevented by using once-only session tokens or time stamping sessions. Kerberos uses Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT)—this contains information about the client (name and IP address) plus a timestamp and validity period.

comments.content:
note, The TGT (or user ticket) is time-stamped (under Windows, they have a default maximum age of 10 hours). This means that workstations and servers on the network must be synchronized (to within five minutes) or a ticket will be rejected. This helps to prevent replay attacks.

Reference COM501B

choices.A: The firewall should be configured to prevent user traffic form matching the implicit deny rule.
choices.D: The firewall should be configured to include an explicit deny rule.
choices.B: The firewall should be configured with access lists to allow inbound and outbound traffic.
choices.C: The firewall should be configured with port security to allow traffic.

discussion.content:
The Answer is A,
Poor write up, though.
A is correct - after further thought "should be configured to prevent user traffic form matching the implicit deny rule" implies ACLs. It doesn't say that the implicit deny will be removed.

comptia - guess what i am thinking off
you should NEVER prevent users from hitting the deny all - after all, it is their for a reason
ACLs might take lots of time to setup, so - guess if comptia refer to an immediate solution (temporary - A) or permanent solution (B)
setting an ACL is fine, but how would you know if you've missed specific software used by the organisation? You need a better picture of what ports and protocols need to be allowed, so its A
Jesus questions are so poorly worded. But yes A is the answer.

“New Firewall”, “Configuration not added”. Firewalls by default have an implicit deny. So configure to not match implicit deny which effectively also means configuring rules to allow inbound and outbound traffic. A is correct
A, prevent user traffic from matching the implicit deny rule.

comments.content:
upon research unconfigured firewall has a rule of deny any any. :( 
still think it should be B though

discussion.content: should be B, as an ''unconfigured firewall'' has rule of allow any any
fw best practise are to setup last rule ( on the bottom) to implicitly deny. It mean deny all which is not mention in a rules above.
B is correct. A would in essence allow ALL traffic - wide open. B would provide access rules to allow only desired traffic.

I agree w/ AnAverageUser, I pondered at this for like an hour.. 

Although the question is poorly worded (a trademark of CompTIA), I believe the question is pointing towards an "immediate" remedy to the current situation which is providing end users immediate access to the rest of the (internal?) organization's network. 

B would be like setting rules at a larger scale for the organzation connecting to an external network/the Internet.
I think it should be B. Since the there are many ways to prent traffic from matching the implicit deny rule. We nee to configure the inbound and outbound user traffic. Does anyone agree ?

comments.content: B would be implying all traffic, not just the users. A should be the answer.

questions.question_text: A new firewall has been places into service at an organization. However, a configuration has not been entered on the firewall. Employees on the network segment covered by the new firewall report they are unable to access the network. Which of the following steps should be completed to BEST resolve the issue?

A security consultant is analyzing data from a recent compromise. The following data points are documented:
✑ Access to data on share drives and certain networked hosts was lost after an employee logged in to an interactive session as a privileged user.
✑ The data was unreadable by any known commercial software.
✑ The issue spread through the enterprise via SMB only when certain users accessed data.
Removal instructions were not available from any major antivirus vendor.
//IMG//

Which of the following types of malware is this an example of?

discussion.content:
Back door

A backdoor attack uses a specific type of malware so hackers can avoid normal authentication procedures to gain access to a target system. As a result, perpetrators can go through all resources such as file servers and databases to issue commands and change system settings without being discovered.

Hackers install backdoors to take control of vulnerable network components, allowing them to carry out targeted attacks. These attacks include website defacement, data theft, server hijacking, watering hole attacks, and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, among others.

comments.content: WannaCry is an example of crypto ransomware, a type of malicious software (malware) used by cybercriminals to extort money. Ransomware does this by either encrypting valuable files, so you are unable to read them, or by locking you out of your computer, so you are not able to use it. Ransomware that uses encryption is called crypto ransomware.
First of all, WannaCry is considered network worm..
WannaCry was a famous ransomware worm that exploited SMB to spread

discussion.content:
What makes B - ransomware the correct answer? Could someone please explain or correct me if I'm wrong? Here's my reasoning:
1. It never asked for ransom
2. It states "Access to data on shared drives and certain network hosts was LOST" and "unreadable". But it never mentioned the data was ENCRYPTED. It could the data was simply corrupted/destroyed by some destroyed disruptive virus

Therefore, I rule out ransomware (B). We also know that the issue spread ONLY when certain users access data, so it's not a worm (E), which can replicate itself without any human interaction. 

We haven't observed any behavior related to a keylogger -> exclude D

And we only have RAT (A) and Backdoor (C) left. To my understanding, RAT is a synonym to backdoor, but may has a little bit more capabilities, such as installing a bunch of other malware, which could delete some data (1) or some data unavailable (2)...??? So maybe the answer is RAT (A)?

I know this seems far-fetched, but it's the only possible conclusion I've left

Degaussing is not entirely fool-proof. It can only be used on magnetic media, and there is no way to guarantee that a particular degaussing machine is strong enough to destroy all the data on every hard drive. Also, degaussing does not provide reporting of the erasure process, which is needed to prove regulatory compliance. Most IT professionals will tell you that degaussing or wiping hard drives is no longer an acceptable method for complete, secure destruction of stored data.

TOTAL HARD DRIVE DESTRUCTION
The best and most secure method of rendering hard drive information completely unusable is to completely destroy it through hard drive shreddin
the site say it's shredding.. but why it can't be degaussing?

comments.content: Shredding physically destroys the disks and makes them definitely unusable, while degaussing still leaves them intact, even if they will still be unusable at that point.

questions.question_text: An organization handling highly confidential information needs to update its systems. Which of the following is the BEST method to prevent data compromise?
